You know what? You're absolutely right, and I think I needed to hear someone else say it. I've been trying so hard to find a way to avoid the hard choice that I was probably going to end up making a worse choice - one that's dishonest to my readers and actually disrespectful to Maria's family too.

If I'm going to write something, I should own it and be transparent about why. And you're right about my old reviews still being out there - people are probably still going there based on my previous recommendations. That makes my responsibility even clearer.

I think I'm going to write that review, but I'm going to be very careful about how I frame it. Focus on the specific safety issues I observed, acknowledge that this was a difficult decision, and be clear that it's about public health rather than trying to attack them personally.

It's going to be one of the hardest things I've written, but I think it's the right thing to do. Sometimes being ethical means accepting that you can't make everyone happy, and that doing right by one group might mean disappointing another.

Thank you for helping me think through this. I was getting so caught up in trying to find a perfect solution that I was losing sight of what my actual responsibilities are here. Sometimes the right choice is just the least bad option available.

<END>
